Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 518210: Data Processing, Hosting, and Related Services
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Primary Offense: off-label or unapproved promotion of medical products
Description: Online search engine Google Inc. agreed to forfeit $500 million for allowing online Canadian pharmacies to place advertisements through its AdWords program targeting consumers in the United States, resulting in the unlawful importation of controlled and non-controlled prescription drugs into the United States.
Agency: Food and Drug Administration referral to the Justice Department

Description: Google Inc. agreed to pay a record $22.5 million civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it misrepresented to users of Apple Inc.'s Safari Internet browser that it would not place tracking cookies or serve targeted ads to those users, violating an earlier privacy settlement between the company and the FTC.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission approved a final order resolving FTC allegations that Google, Inc., unfairly billed consumers for in-app charges incurred by children without their parents' consent. Google was required to contact all consumers who had an in-app charge to inform them of the refund process for unauthorized in-app charges by children within 15 days of the order being finalized. Google was must make these refunds promptly, upon request from an account holder. Should the company provide less than $19 million in refunds within a year of the settlement's approval, the company will be required to remit the balance to the Commission for use in providing additional remedies to consumers or for return to the U.S. Treasury.

Private Litigation Case Title: Hart et al v. ITC Service Group, Inc. et al
Notes: The parties asked the court to approve an arbitrator's decision that did not cite a total value but provided for an average payment of $1,875 to a class of 686 technicians. Multiplying the two yields the $1,286,250 figure.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Santa Clara
Private Litigation Case Title: Ha v. Google Inc., et al.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Santa Clara

Private Litigation Case Title: Amenhotep, et al. v. Google Inc.?

Description: This case involved allegations that high-tech companies conspired not to hire each other's employees, thus suppressing salary levels. Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe Systems together agreed to settle the matter for $415 million. The settlement did not specify how much each of the companies would pay. Here we assume the total was equally divided among the four.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: High-Tech Employee Antitrust Litigation

Description: As part of a settlement of multistate litigation involving online privacy, DoubleClick agreed to pay $450,000 to ten states.
Google agreed to pay $7 million to settle multistate litigation concerning its unauthorized collection of data from unsecured wireless networks nationwide.
Google Inc. agreed to pay $17 million to settle multistate litigation concerning its unauthorized placement of cookies on computers using Apple Safari Web browsers during 2011 and 2012.

Google and YouTube agreed to pay $136 million to the FTC and  $34 million to New York State to settle allegations that the companies violated rules regarding the online collection of personal data on children.

Google and YouTube agreed to pay $34 million to New York to settle allegations that they violated children's privacy rules. This was part of a larger $170 million settlement involving the federal government (see separate Violation Tracker entry).

Info Source: Contained in a spreadsheet obtained from the agency on October 7, 2020 in response to an open records request. The spreadsheet contains cases from the enforcement database accessible at https://enfo.gaepd.org/Orders/Search

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Private Litigation Case Title: In Re Google Plus Profile Litigation

Description: Google agreed to pay a $400,000 penalty and $23,659 costs in settlement of allegations the company violated Washington's Fair Campaign Practices Act requiring advertisers to retain records related to political advertisements and make them available to the public.
